introduction: This lesson will focus on how to give and ask for directions. Students will learn basic vocabulary related to directions and common phrases used in simple dialogues. Additionally, we will cover simple grammatical structures such as imperative sentences (e.g., 'Turn left,' 'Go straight') and questions starting with 'Where is...' or 'How do I get to...'.
presentation:
New Vocabulary:

  • Left
  • Right
  • Straight
  • Near
  • Far
  • Turn
  • Next to
  • Opposite
  • Between
  • Corner
  • Cross
  • Traffic light
  • Street
  • Block
  • Map

Example Sentences:

  • Turn left at the corner.
  • Go straight until you see the traffic light.
  • The bank is next to the supermarket.
  • Where is the nearest bus stop?
  • How do I get to the train station?

data: The pharmacy is (near / far) the restaurant.
(How / Where) do I get to the train station?
The hotel is (next to / between) the hospital.

conclusion:
Review:

Review the vocabulary and grammar structures covered in this lesson.

Example Dialogues:

  • Excuse me, where is the bus station? It’s next to the post office.
  • How do I get to the museum? Go straight and turn right at the corner.

Questions for Review:

  • What do you say when you want someone to turn left?
  • How do you ask where something is?

Homework:

Write a short dialogue (at least 5 lines) where you ask for directions to a place and receive an answer. Use at least 5 new words from today’s lesson.
